description: Family kitchen wisdom aggregated from all collections

tips.text: Test yeast by dissolving it in warm water (105-110¬∞F) with a pinch of sugar. It should foam within 10 minutes.
Bread dough has risen enough when you poke it with your finger and the indent springs back slowly.
For a crispy crust, place a pan of water in the bottom of the oven while baking.
Let bread cool completely before slicing - cutting hot bread makes it gummy.
Brush the top of bread with butter immediately after removing from oven for a soft, golden crust.
Bring eggs and butter to room temperature before baking - they incorporate better and create fluffier cakes.
Don't open the oven door during the first 20 minutes of baking - the cold air can cause cakes to fall.
Test cake doneness by inserting a toothpick in the center - it should come out clean or with just a few moist crumbs.
Let cakes cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to finish cooling.
For level cake layers, wrap wet cloth strips around the outside of the pan while baking.
Chill cookie dough for at least 30 minutes before baking - it prevents spreading and improves flavor.
Use parchment paper or silicone mats - cookies bake more evenly and cleanup is easy.
Rotate cookie sheets halfway through baking for even browning.
Remove cookies from the oven when they look slightly underdone - they continue to bake on the hot sheet.

If you use 100-percent-corn-oil margarine in your cookies, keep in mind that your dough will be softer than doughs made with regular margarine or butter. (Do not use spread, diet, or soft-style margarine products in cookie doughs. Your cookies will not turn out satisfactorily.) When using corn-oil margarine, make the following adjustments so your dough will be easier to handle: For sliced cookies, chill the rolls of dough in the freezer instead of the refrigerator. For rolled cookies, chill the dough before rolling it, or freeze it just until it's firm enough to roll. With a standard mixer, start mixing on low speed so you don't sling the flour out of the bowl. If you use a portable mixer when making cookies and notice that it strains or becomes hot, stir in any remaining ingredients by hand. Many cookie doughs are so stiff that beating them with a portable mixer may not be possible, especially when you're adding the last of the flour.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cookies chapter

tips.text: Drop-cookie doughs tend to spread more than other cookie doughs do. So, to keep them from spreading too much, drop them onto cool cookie sheets. Be sure, too, to let cookie sheets that are straight from the oven cool for several minutes before reusing.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cookies chapter

tips.text: For nicely rounded sliced cookies, follow these hints: To prevent the rolls from developing a flat side, gently roll them on a flat surface several times while they chill. Make sure the rolls of dough are well chilled before slicing. (Chill them in the freezer if you used corn-oil margarine.) If the slices become misshapen, reshape them with your fingers.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cookies chapter

tips.text: For high altitude baking, increase oven temperature from 400¬∞F to 425¬∞F for muffins.
For high altitude, no adjustments needed for dumplings.
For high altitude, heat oven to 475¬∞F (instead of 450¬∞F). If using water, increase baking mix to 2 1/2 cups.
For deep-dish pumpkin pie at high altitude, extend second bake time to 55-65 minutes. For shallow pies, no change needed.
Insert a knife about 1 to 1 1/2 inches from the edge of the pie. If it comes out clean, or if tiny bubbles around the edge of the pie or filling separate, remove the pie from the oven immediately.

Combine dry ingredients into bowl; make a well. Combine beaten egg, milk, and melted shortening (cooled slightly). Add to dry ingredients all at once. Stir quickly just until moistened - overmixing causes tough muffins.
If batter is overbeaten, muffins will have peaks on top, dull crusts, and tunneled texture. Stir batter only until just moistened for best results.
Make cleanup easy by lining muffin tin with paper bake cups.

For a shiny golden crust, use Egg Glaze (mix 1 slightly beaten egg with 1 Tbsp. water or milk) or Egg Yolk Glaze (mix 1 slightly beaten egg yolk with 1 Tbsp. water or milk). Apply with pastry brush after rolls rise, just before baking.
For a shiny chewy crust (lighter in color), use Egg White Glaze: Mix 1 slightly beaten egg white with 1 Tbsp. water. Apply with pastry brush after rolls rise, just before baking.

Preheat conventional oven to 200¬∞F/93¬∞C for 5 minutes, then turn off oven. Shape dough, place on baking pan as directed and cover with a clean kitchen towel. Place dough in oven until doubled in size. This will reduce rising time by about one-half.

Recipes using whole grain or unrefined flours contain less gluten and may not rise as much as those using white bread flour. As a result, these heavier breads may fall slightly in the center. This is normal and will not affect the taste. Wheat gluten can also be added to improve the shape and volume of bread made with low gluten flours.

Have you noticed rims around the edges of your nut breads and muffins instead of evenly rounded tops? There's a simple remedy to this problem: grease the baking pans or muffin cups on the bottom and only ¬Ω inch up the sides. Do this and your batter will cling to the sides of the pan instead of sliding back down during baking. (Don't use nonstick spray coating in muffin cups because it will coat too high up on the sides.)
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, quick breads chapter

tips.text: Nut breads are best if stored overnight before slicing. The flavors mellow and the loaves are easier to slice. Just follow these steps: After baking, let the loaves cool completely on a wire rack, then wrap them in foil or clear plastic wrap and store them at room temperature. Use these other tips, too, when making nut breads: Check the bread 10 to 15 minutes before the baking time is completed. Cover with foil if it's browning too fast. Don't be concerned about the crack down the top of the loaf. This is typical of nut breads.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, quick breads chapter

tips.text: Here's how to make the sour milk called for in some of our recipes. For each cup of sour milk, place 1 tablespoon lemon juice or vinegar in a glass measuring cup. Add enough milk to make 1 cup total liquid; stir. Let the mixture stand 5 minutes before using.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, quick breads chapter

tips.text: Follow these tips when baking cakes: Use the exact ingredients listed in a recipe. Substitutions, such as shortening for margarine or butter, will alter the cake's texture and flavor. Turn your oven on to preheat, then start mixing your cake. Your oven should be preheated (allow 10 to 15 minutes) at about the same time you're done mixing the cake. Cool layer cakes in their pans on wire racks for 10 minutes (loaf cakes, 15 minutes), then loosen the edges. Place an inverted rack on each cake and turn over; lift off the pan. Place a second rack over the cake and invert again. Invert angel, sponge, and chiffon cakes in their pans as soon as they are removed from the oven to prevent them from shrinking or falling. Then cool completely.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cakes chapter

tips.text: Use a paper towel or pastry brush to evenly spread a thin layer of solid vegetable shortening on the bottom and sides of the pan. For an 8- or 9-inch round pan, use about 1/2 tablespoon; for a 13x9x2-inch pan, use 1 tablespoon. Then add a tablespoon or two of all-purpose flour and shake the pan to coat evenly. Tap out the excess flour. To easily remove a cake from its pan, make sure to grease and flour the pan. If you plan to leave a cake in the pan for serving (as with a snack cake), grease only the bottom.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cakes chapter

tips.text: Two-layer cakes suit some occasions, and carry-in-the-pan cakes are handy for picnics and potlucks. Fill baking pans no more than half full. Use any remaining batter to make some cupcakes. Baking times are approximate and may vary from cake to cake. At 350¬∞ oven: Two 8x1¬Ω-inch round baking pans = 35 to 40 minutes. Two 9x1¬Ω-inch round baking pans = 30 to 35 minutes. Two 8x8x2-inch baking pans = 25 to 35 minutes. Two 9x9x2-inch baking pans = 25 to 35 minutes. One 13x9x2-inch baking pan = 30 to 35 minutes. One 15x10x1-inch baking pan = 25 to 30 minutes. Cupcakes (half full of batter) = 18 to 23 minutes.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cakes chapter

tips.text: Create a special cake by using one of the following suggestions with a yellow, white, or chocolate two-layer cake mix. Add one of these to the dry cake mix: ¬æ teaspoon ground cinnamon, ¬º teaspoon ground ginger, ¬º teaspoon ground allspice, or ¬º teaspoon ground nutmeg. Add one of these with the eggs: ¬Ω cup applesauce, 1 tablespoon instant coffee crystals (dissolved in the water called for in the mix directions), 1 tablespoon finely shredded orange peel, 1 teaspoon maple flavoring, or ¬º teaspoon almond extract. Substitute an equal amount of unsweetened pineapple juice for the water in a white or yellow cake mix. Stir one of these into the mixed cake batter: 1 cup coconut, ¬Ω cup finely chopped nuts, ¬Ω cup miniature semisweet chocolate pieces, or ¬Ω cup well-drained, chopped maraschino cherries. To one-third of the white or yellow cake batter, add a half cup chocolate-flavored syrup. Pour the plain batter into the baking pans; pour chocolate batter on top of the plain batter. Swirl gently with a spatula.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cakes chapter

tips.text: If you live more than 3,000 feet above sea level, use this chart to adjust cake ingredients listed. Try the smaller amounts first, then make any necessary adjustments next time around. At 3,000 feet: Liquid - add 1 to 2 tablespoons for each cup; Baking powder - decrease ¬º teaspoon for each teaspoon; Sugar - decrease 0 to 1 tablespoon for each cup. At 5,000 feet: Liquid - add 2 to 4 tablespoons for each cup; Baking powder - decrease ‚Öõ to ¬º teaspoon for each teaspoon; Sugar - decrease 0 to 2 tablespoons for each cup. At 7,000 feet: Liquid - add 3 to 4 tablespoons for each cup; Baking powder - decrease ¬º teaspoon for each teaspoon; Sugar - decrease 1 to 3 tablespoons for each cup.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cakes chapter

tips.text: Keep everything cold when making pie crust - cold butter creates flaky layers.
Don't overwork pie dough - mix just until it comes together. Overworking makes it tough.
Brush pie crust with beaten egg for a golden, shiny finish.
Place a baking sheet under fruit pies to catch any drips.
Let fruit pies cool completely before cutting - the filling needs time to set.

When planning party beverages: (1) Expect 1 1/2 oz liquor per bar drink - about 16 drinks from a 750ml bottle. (2) Chill beer to 45-50¬∞F. For quick chilling, place bottles/cans in a deep tub of ice cubes. (3) Expect 3 oz wine per drink - about 8 drinks from a 750ml bottle. For bigger parties, buy 1.5-liter bottles. (4) Offer nonalcoholic options like eggnog, punch, or homemade soda pop. (5) Keep punches cold with ice rings made in ring molds. For decorative ice rings, line mold with citrus slices, berries, or melon balls, add water to cover fruit, freeze, then fill and freeze again. (6) You only need two types of glasses: 10-12 oz all-purpose glasses and 9-10 oz stemmed wineglasses. Disposable plastic glasses work well for large parties.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, beverages chapter

tips.text: Absolute rules no longer dictate which wine to serve with what food. Just follow your personal tastes. If you're unsure, ask an informed store employee to help you make a choice.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, beverages chapter

tips.text: To determine the freshness and quality of your yeast: 1) Place 1/2 cup of lukewarm water into a small bowl or cup. 2) Stir 1 tsp. of sugar into the water. 3) Sprinkle 2 tsp. of yeast over the surface. 4) Place bowl or cup in a warm area and allow it to sit for 10 minutes undisturbed. 5) The mixture should foam and produce a strong yeast aroma. If this does not occur, the yeast is inactive and stale and new yeast should be purchased.

At high altitudes above 3,000 feet, dough rises faster. Follow these guidelines (use one at a time): 1) Reduce the amount of yeast by 25% to inhibit over-rising. 2) Increase salt by 25% - the bread will rise slower and have less tendency to sink. 3) Watch your dough as it mixes - flour stored at high altitudes tends to be drier, so you might need to add a few tablespoons of water until the dough forms a nice ball.

Kneading should be done on a lightly floured surface, a board or counter top; add a little more flour if the dough remains sticky. Knead 8 to 10 minutes until smooth and elastic; it should have tiny air bubbles under the surface. Turn the dough onto a lightly floured board or counter top. With lightly floured hands, shape the dough into a ball and fold it toward you. With the heels of hands, using a rolling motion, push it away. Give dough a quarter of a turn. Repeat for 8 to 10 minutes; dough should no longer stick and will be ready for second rising or shaping, as recipe directs.

When a recipe gives a range for the flour amount, use the minimum as a guide and knead in as much of the remaining flour as you can. Knead the dough to the stiffness called for in the recipe. Kneading develops the gluten of the flour, which determines the final structure of the bread loaf. To knead, fold the dough over and push down with the heel of your hand, curving your fingers over the dough. Give the dough a quarter-turn, then fold over and push down again. Continue this fold-push-turn procedure until the dough is smooth and elastic.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: Don't raise dough in a hot area because excessive heat will kill the yeast. Too much cold, on the other hand, will stunt the yeast's growth. The optimum temperature for raising dough is 80¬∞F. For best results, place the bowl of dough in an unheated oven, then set a large pan of hot water under the bowl on the oven's lower rack. Let dough rise till it's nearly doubled in size. Don't let loaves rise to the top of the pan because the dough needs room to rise as it bakes.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: For a soft and shiny crust, brush loaves with margarine or butter after baking. For a glossy, crispy crust, brush before baking with milk, water, or beaten egg. Test for doneness by tapping the top of the loaf with your finger. A hollow sound means the loaf is properly baked.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: If you live at a high altitude, expect yeast doughs to rise faster than at sea level. The higher you live, the faster the doughs will rise.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: Here's how to identify the stiffness of dough specified in bread recipes: Soft dough is too sticky to knead and is often used for batter breads. Moderately soft dough is slightly sticky, may be kneaded on a floured surface, and is used for most sweet breads. Moderately stiff dough is somewhat firm to the touch, kneads easily on a floured surface, and is used for most unsweet breads. Stiff dough is firm to the touch and is easily rolled on a floured surface. French bread is made from this type of dough.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: When baking several long, individual, or round loaves of bread at the same time, you'll need an extra large (17x14-inch) baking sheet. If you don't have this size baking sheet, go ahead and shape the loaves on two smaller baking sheets and let them rise as directed. Then, while you're baking one sheet, place the other one in the refrigerator. Don't bake the two smaller sheets at the same time because too little air would circulate in the oven.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: With a little help from your microwave oven, you may be able to significantly shorten the time it takes to proof (raise) your yeast breads. Before you begin, check your owner's manual to see if proofing is recommended. Or use the following test to check your oven: Place 2 tablespoons cold stick margarine in a custard cup in the center of your oven. Micro-cook, uncovered, on 10% power (low) for 4 minutes. If the margarine doesn't completely melt, your microwave can proof yeast dough. But if the margarine does completely melt, your microwave will kill the yeast before the bread has a chance to rise. If so, you'll have to raise your yeast breads conventionally. If your oven passed the test, here's how to proceed: While kneading your dough, place 3 cups water in a 4-cup measure. Cook on 100% power (high) for 6¬Ω to 8¬Ω minutes or till boiling. Move measure to back of oven. Place kneaded dough in a greased bowl, turning once. Cover with waxed paper and place in microwave oven with hot water. Heat dough and water on 10% power (low) for 13 to 15 minutes or till dough has almost doubled. Punch dough down; shape as directed. Then place shaped dough in 8x4x2- or 9x5x3-inch loaf dishes. Return to microwave with hot water. Cover with waxed paper. Heat on low 6 to 8 minutes or till nearly doubled. (For round or long loaves that are shaped on baking sheets, or rolls that are shaped in muffin cups, you'll have to do the second proofing step conventionally.) For rich yeast breads (those with eggs and a slightly higher proportion of sugar), proofing times will be slightly longer. Allow 15 to 20 minutes for the first proofing time, and 10 to 14 minutes for the second proofing time.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: The bread recipes in this chapter were tested with active dry yeast. You can, however, prepare these recipes (except Sourdough Starter) using quick-rising active dry yeast. Just follow the same directions. The dough should rise in about a third less time, especially during the second rising step.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: Most of our yeast breads use the electric-mixer method, which calls for the dry yeast to be combined directly with the flour. But if you don't have an electric mixer, or if you live in Canada, where the available yeast doesn't work well using this method, use the hand-mixed method described on page 38. Here's how to convert recipes to this method: Change ¬º cup of the liquid to warm water; add yeast to dissolve. Heat remaining liquid and continue as directed in the instructions on page 38.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: Butterhorns: Lightly grease baking sheets. On a lightly floured surface, roll each half of dough into a 12-inch circle. Brush with melted margarine or butter. Cut each circle into 12 wedges. To shape, begin at wide end of wedge and roll toward point. Place, point side down, 2 to 3 inches apart on baking sheets. Let rise and bake as directed. Makes 24 rolls. Rosettes: Lightly grease baking sheets. Divide each half of dough into 16 pieces. On a lightly floured surface, roll each piece into a 12-inch rope. Tie in a loose knot, leaving 2 long ends. Tuck top end under roll. Bring bottom end up and tuck into center of roll. Place 2 to 3 inches apart on baking sheet. Let rise and bake as directed. Makes 32 rolls. Parker House Rolls: Lightly grease baking sheets. On a lightly floured surface, roll each half of dough to ¬º-inch thickness. Cut with a floured 2¬Ω-inch-round cutter. Brush with melted margarine or butter. Use the dull edge of a table knife to make an off-center crease in each round. Fold each round along the crease so the large half is on top. Press folded edge firmly. (Dough will recede during baking, making the top half shorter than the bottom one.) Place rolls 2 to 3 inches apart on baking sheets. Let rise and bake as directed. Makes 30 rolls. Cloverleaves: Lightly grease 24 muffin cups. Divide each half of dough into 36 pieces. Shape each piece into a ball, pulling edges under to make a smooth top. Place three balls in each greased muffin cup, smooth side up. Let rise; bake as directed. Makes 24. Shortcut Cloverleaves: Lightly grease 24 muffin cups. Divide each half of dough into 12 pieces. Shape each piece into a ball. Place one ball in each muffin cup. With floured scissors, snip top in half, then snip again to make 4 points. Let rise, bake as directed. Makes 24.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, breads chapter

tips.text: Divide dough into 12 equal pieces, shape into balls and place in greased muffin cups. Cover, let rise and bake as directed.

Makes 12. Lightly grease 12 muffin cups. Divide dough into 36 1-inch pieces. Pull edges under, smoothing tops to shape into balls. Place 3 balls in each muffin cup, smooth-side-up. Cover, let rise and bake as directed.

Makes 12. Lightly grease 8 x 1-1/2-inch, or 9 x 1-1/2 inch round baking pan. Divide dough into 12 pieces. Shape each piece into a ball, pulling edges under to make a smooth top. Arrange rolls smooth-side-up in prepared pan. Cover, let rise and bake as directed.

Makes 10. Lightly grease baking sheet. Divide dough into 10 equal pieces. On a lightly floured surface, using your hand, roll each piece into a pencil-like strand about 10 inches long. Beginning at the center, continue wrapping each piece around the center to form a swirl. Place rolls 2-3 inches apart on prepared baking sheet. Cover, let rise and bake as directed.

Makes 12. Lightly grease baking sheet. On lightly floured surface, roll dough into a 12-inch circle. Brush dough with melted butter. Cut into 12 wedges. To shape rolls, begin at wide end of wedge and roll toward point. Place rolls point side down, 2 to 3 inches apart, on prepared baking sheet. Cover, let rise and bake as directed.

Altitude, weather conditions, and accuracy in measurement can affect the outcome of a loaf. Begin using the smaller amount of liquid. Allow bread maker to mix ingredients for a few minutes before checking dough consistency. If dough is dense, oddly shaped, or unit is making a knocking noise, add 1 Tbsp. water at a time until the dough is soft and pliable. Do not exceed 4-1/2 cups dry ingredients.

Unlike yeast breads, quick breads do not use yeast as the rising agent. The knead and rise cycles are omitted. Instead, quick breads use baking powder or baking soda along with steam as leavening. Select Quick Bread setting, let mix for 5 minutes, scrape down sides with rubber spatula. When finished, let cool in pan 5 minutes before removing to wire rack. Cool completely before slicing.

Press Select button to reach dough setting. Press 'Start/Stop'. When dough is ready, the unit will signal and display reads 0:00. Press 'Start/Stop' holding it down until you hear a beep. To remove the bread pan, grasp handle firmly and lift pan out. NOTE: The pan does not get hot when using the dough setting.

1) Lightly sprinkle all-purpose flour onto a pastry mat or board. Using a rubber spatula or wooden spoon, remove dough from the bread pan and place on lightly floured surface. Knead by hand 2 or 3 times to release the air. If the dough is easy to handle without flour, shape on a lightly oiled, clean countertop. 2) Shape dough into your favourite rolls, coffee cake, etc. Place on greased baking pan. Cover dough with a clean cloth and let rise until almost doubled in size, about 1 hour. 3) Bake as directed in the recipe. Remove from pan and cool on a wire rack or serve warm.
Use a candy thermometer - 235¬∞F is the soft ball stage. Don't guess!
On humid days, cook candy 2 degrees higher than the recipe calls for.
At high altitude, reduce the target temperature by 2¬∞F for every 1000 feet above sea level.
Never stir candy while it's boiling unless the recipe specifically says to - it causes crystallization.
Cool candy on a buttered surface or parchment paper, never wax paper - it can stick and melt.

Thread stage (230¬∞ to 233¬∞): When a teaspoon is dipped into the hot mixture then removed, the candy falls off the spoon in a fine, thin thread. Soft-ball stage (234¬∞ to 240¬∞): When the ball of candy is removed from cold water, the candy instantly flattens and runs between your fingers. Firm-ball stage (244¬∞ to 248¬∞): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it is firm enough to hold its shape, but quickly flattens at room temperature. Hard-ball stage (250¬∞ to 266¬∞): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it doesn't flatten until pressed. Soft-crack stage (270¬∞ to 290¬∞): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, but pliable and elastic, threads. Hard-crack stage (295¬∞ to 310¬∞): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, brittle threads that snap easily.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, candy chapter

tips.text: Most candies will stay fresh for two to three weeks if kept tightly covered in a cool, dry place. Store different types of candies separately. Layer brittles and toffees between sheets of waxed paper in airtight containers. Wrap fudge and fondant in foil or clear plastic wrap and place in airtight containers. Store divinity in airtight containers lined with waxed paper.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, candy chapter

tips.text: Candy mixtures should boil at a moderate, steady rate over their entire surface. To guide you, our recipes list suggested range-top temperatures for cooking the candy mixtures. Depending on your range, though, you may have to use slightly higher or lower temperatures to cook the candy mixtures within the recommended times. Cooking too fast or slow will make candies too hard or soft.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, candy chapter

tips.text: First, place the thermometer in boiling water for a few minutes, then read it. If the thermometer registers above or below 212¬∞, add or subtract the same difference in degrees from the recipe temperature. For an accurate reading, make sure the bulb of the thermometer is completely covered with liquid, not just foam, and that it doesn't touch the bottom of the pan.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, candy chapter

tips.text: The easiest way to coat candy is to dip it into confectioners' coating. Confectioners' coating is a chocolatelike product that also is called white chocolate, almond bark, or summer coating. It usually comes in chocolate and vanilla flavors. What makes confectioners' coating so easy is that it doesn't speckle as it hardens and that it easily heats without scorching. Before dipping candy, chop the coating and melt it in a heavy saucepan over low heat. Semisweet chocolate and milk chocolate also can be used for dipping. But these products usually need to be tempered (melted and then cooled to the correct dipping temperature). Without tempering, the chocolate often speckles or develops gray streaks as it hardens. This speckling is called blooming and affects only the appearance, not the quality or flavor, of the candy. If a small amount of speckling doesn't bother you, go ahead and use untempered chocolate for dipping. To learn more about tempering, see a candy-making cookbook.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, candy chapter

tips.text: Tomatoes should be ripe but still firm for juice. Start with the smaller amount of horseradish and add more until you get the zest you like. For pressure canning, process pints for 15 minutes at 10 pounds pressure (adjust for altitude). For freezing, cool juice and pour into wide-top freezer containers, leaving 1/2-inch headspace.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 199

tips.text: Whether to use natural or process cheese for a dish can sometimes be confusing. In our recipes, we specifically call for process cheese when we have found that it is necessary for easy, smooth melting. If the word "process" is not mentioned in the ingredient list (for example, 1/2 cup shredded Swiss cheese), you can use either process cheese or natural cheese successfully.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, eggs and cheese chapter

tips.text: When frying or cooking foods a few at a time, here's how to keep the early batches warm until serving time. Arrange fried foods and waffles in a single layer on a wire rack. Set the rack atop a baking sheet and place it in a 300¬∞ oven. To keep pancakes or French toast warm, put them on an ovenproof plate and place them in a 300¬∞ oven.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, quick breads chapter

tips.text: Chocolate-dipped fruit can be used to decorate cakes and desserts or served on their own with coffee. Insert a wooden skewer into a non-juicy fresh fruit or candied fruit. Dip half of it into melted semisweet chocolate. Slide fruit off skewer onto pan lined with waxed paper. Use strawberries, grapes, orange sections, dried apricots, and prunes or other seasonal fruits.

Take your favorite pudding and create a whole new dessert with one of these easy-to-fix ideas: For cream tarts, spoon pudding into baked tart shells. For parfaits, layer pudding and canned fruit-pie filling in parfait glasses. For frozen pops, spoon pudding into 3-ounce paper cups, cover with foil, insert wooden sticks through the foil into the pudding, and freeze till firm. For sauce, stir additional milk into the pudding till of desired consistency, and serve over fruit or cake.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, desserts chapter

tips.text: Let your homemade ice cream ripen for four hours to blend its flavors. To ripen the ice cream, remove the dasher, then cover the freezer can with waxed paper or foil. Plug the hole in the lid. Place it on the can. Pack the outer freezer bucket with enough ice and rock salt to cover the top of the freezer can. (Use 4 cups ice per 1 cup salt.)
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, desserts chapter

tips.text: Here are two soda-shop treats you can make at home: Saucy Scoops - Top scoops of ice cream with a sauce, whipped cream, and nuts. Banana Splits - For each serving, cut a banana in half lengthwise and place in a dessert dish. Add three scoops of ice cream. Top one with marshmallow creme, one with Hot Fudge Sauce, and one with Fruit Sauce. Top with whipped cream, nuts, and maraschino cherries.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, desserts chapter

tips.text: When you've whipped more cream than you need, freeze the extra. Just spoon the whipped cream into mounds on a baking sheet lined with waxed paper. Freeze till firm, then transfer the mounds to a freezer container. Freeze up to 1 month. To serve, let stand 5 minutes, then place on top of dessert.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, desserts chapter

tips.text: For easy-peel hard boiled eggs, use eggs that are at least a week old.
Add a splash of vinegar to poaching water - it helps the egg whites hold together.
For fluffier scrambled eggs, add a splash of water instead of milk.
To separate eggs cleanly, crack them into your hand and let the whites slip through your fingers.

Purchase clean, fresh eggs from refrigerated display cases. Select large eggs. White or brown eggs have the same nutrition content. Refrigerate eggs promptly with the large ends up; use within one week for best quality (store up to five weeks). Always discard eggs with broken or cracked shells due to salmonella risk. Serve hot egg dishes right away. Refrigerate chilled egg dishes immediately after mixing, and keep them cold until serving time. Chill leftovers or make-ahead dishes containing eggs promptly. Some experts believe using uncooked or slightly cooked eggs in recipes such as mayonnaise, meringue pie, or Caesar salad may be harmful to some people because of possible salmonella contamination. The same is true of over-easy eggs and sunny-side-up eggs. If you are elderly, ill, or otherwise at risk, you may wish to avoid these recipes.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, eggs chapter

tips.text: A souffl√© makes a great entr√©e when you're entertaining because it bakes for almost an hour, giving you time to socialize. Just make the salad and side dishes ahead, then pop the souffl√© into the oven when your guests arrive. Just before the souffl√© finishes baking, gather everyone around the table. Then present the spectacular dish.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, eggs chapter

tips.text: Test oil temperature by dropping in a small piece of bread - it should sizzle and turn golden in about 60 seconds at 350¬∞F.
Don't overcrowd the pan when frying - it drops the oil temperature and makes food soggy.
Drain fried foods on a wire rack, not paper towels - they stay crispier.
Let oil come back to temperature between batches for consistent results.
Read the entire recipe before starting - no surprises!
Mise en place - prepare and measure all ingredients before you start cooking.
Taste as you go and adjust seasonings throughout cooking.
Clean as you go - a tidy kitchen makes cooking more enjoyable.
When in doubt, add more garlic!

Quick-soak method: Combine beans and water in saucepan, bring to boiling, simmer 2 minutes, remove from heat, cover and let stand 1 hour. Overnight method: Place beans and water in bowl, cover and set in cool place for 6 to 8 hours or overnight. After soaking, always drain and rinse beans before cooking.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 161

tips.text: Common dried legumes include: Red kidney beans, Pinto beans, Navy beans, Black-eyed peas, Large lima beans, Red beans, Garbanzo beans (chickpeas), Soybeans, Lentils, Black beans, Split peas (yellow and green), and Great northern beans. Most require soaking before cooking except lentils and split peas.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 161

tips.text: Pumpkin Pie is a custard type pie and freezing is not recommended. However, you can prepare the pie shell ahead of time and freeze separately for up to one month. Defrost, ensure filling ingredients are well mixed, then pour into the frozen crust and bake as usual.
Let meat rest after cooking - this allows juices to redistribute. Rest for 5 minutes per inch of thickness.
Pat meat dry before searing - moisture prevents proper browning.
Season meat generously with salt at least 40 minutes before cooking, or right before - anything in between draws out moisture.
Use a meat thermometer for perfect doneness every time. Don't guess!
Bring meat to room temperature before cooking for more even results.
Marinating is a cinch if you use a plastic bag. The meat stays in the marinade bag and it's easy to turn and rearrange. Cleanup is easy too. Just toss the bag.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 220

tips.text: Venison can have a gamey flavor. Marinating overnight in a mixture of oil, vinegar, and seasonings helps mellow the flavor. For pot roasts and braised dishes, long slow cooking tenderizes the meat. Venison is very lean, so add oil when cooking and avoid overcooking which can make it dry.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 240

tips.text: Rabbit is a lean, mild-tasting meat similar to chicken. Domestic rabbit is more tender than wild rabbit. For a family-friendly version of beer-braised rabbit, substitute apple juice for the beer.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 240

tips.text: Partially freezing beef makes it much easier to slice thinly. Place the meat in the freezer for 30-45 minutes before slicing for fajitas, stir-fry, or other dishes requiring thin strips.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 220

tips.text: In a bowl, micro-cook chocolate, uncovered, on 100% power (high) 1 to 2 minutes for 1 square (1 ounce) (1 1/2 to 2 1/2 minutes for one 6-ounce package [1 cup] chocolate pieces) or till soft enough to stir smooth, stirring every minute.
In a bowl, micro-cook butter/margarine, uncovered, on 100% power (high) 40 to 50 seconds for 2 tablespoons, 45 to 60 seconds for 1/4 cup, or 1 to 2 minutes for 1/2 cup.
In a bowl, heat margarine/butter, uncovered, on 10% power (low) 1 to 1 1/2 minutes for 1/2 cup or till softened.
In a bowl, heat cream cheese, uncovered, on 100% power (high) 15 to 30 seconds for 3 ounces (45 to 60 seconds for 8 ounces) or till softened.
Place muffins or rolls on a plate. Heat, uncovered, on 100% power (high) 15 to 20 seconds for 1 or 2 muffins (30 to 60 seconds for 4 muffins).
Heat, uncovered, on 100% power (high) 30 to 60 seconds for 1/2 cup syrup (1 to 1 1/2 minutes for 1 cup syrup) or till warm.
Heat 1 pint solidly frozen ice cream in a container, uncovered, on 100% power (high) for 15 seconds or till soft.
In a bowl, combine one 10- to 11-ounce can condensed soup and 1 soup can water. Micro-cook, uncovered, on 100% power (high) for 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 minutes or till hot.
Halve or quarter 1 lemon. Heat on 100% power (high) for 30 to 45 seconds. Squeeze out juice.
To keep a cake baked in the microwave oven moist, cover the cooled cake with plastic wrap. Better yet, frost it.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, cakes chapter

tips.text: Fish is an excellent source of protein and generally low in calories. Per 4oz serving typical values: Baked fish with mushrooms ~186 cal, 7g fat; Fish and chips ~820 cal, 56g fat; Shrimp Creole ~301 cal, 8g fat; Grilled salmon steaks ~458 cal, 22g fat; Crab cakes ~241 cal, 13g fat. Cooking method greatly affects nutrition - baked and poached are lowest in fat, fried is highest. See BHG cookbook page 164 for complete nutrition analysis of 50+ fish recipes.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 164

tips.text: Place completely unwrapped package of cream cheese in microwaveable bowl. Microwave on HIGH 10 sec. or just until softened.

Cut pomegranate in half horizontally. Hold cut-side down over a bowl and whack the back firmly with a wooden spoon - seeds will fall out. Alternatively, score the skin into quarters, submerge in a bowl of water, and break apart. Seeds sink, white pith floats. This method is less messy and prevents juice stains.

Zest lemons before juicing - it's much easier on a whole fruit. Use a microplane or fine grater and only remove the yellow part; the white pith is bitter. One medium lemon yields about 1 tablespoon of zest. For recipes calling for both zest and juice, zest first, then roll the lemon firmly on the counter before juicing to get more juice.

Use pure canned pumpkin (not pumpkin pie filling, which has sugar and spices added). If mixture seems watery, spread pumpkin on paper towels for 10 minutes to absorb excess moisture. One 15-oz can equals about 1 3/4 cups. Leftover pumpkin freezes well in portions for up to 3 months.

Fresh ginger can be intimidating if you don't know how to attack it, but there's an easy solution‚Äîand it isn't the powdered stuff! Simply use a spoon to scrape the skin off all those knobby nooks and crannies. Then slice or grate according to your recipe.
Arrange frozen biscuits on paper towel on microwavable plate. Cover with paper towel and microwave on medium (50%): 2 biscuits 1-1.5 min, 4 biscuits 1.5-2 min, 6 biscuits 2-2.5 min.
To prevent lumps in gravy, whisk the flour into cold liquid before adding to hot drippings.
Don't rush the roux - cook it for at least 2 minutes to remove the raw flour taste.
Strain lumpy gravy through a fine mesh sieve - no one will ever know!
Add a pat of cold butter at the end for a glossy, restaurant-quality sauce.

Whether you eat shellfish steamed or boiled, or use them in classic dishes like Crab Mornay or Lobster Newburg, you'll find them irresistible. Shellfish are available live, partially prepared, boiled, or canned. When buying live shellfish, look for oysters and clams that close their shells when you tap them. Buy partially prepared shellfish include shelled oysters, peeled and deveined shrimp with heads removed, and whole cooked crabs. These should have a mild, fresh smell - not ammonia.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 178

tips.text: For each serving you'll need: 6 oysters or clams in the shell, 1/4 cup shucked oysters or clams, 4-12 mussels in the shell, 1/2 to 1 whole lobster or crab, 3 to 4 ounces of lobster tail, 6 ounces shrimp in shells or 3 to 4 ounces peeled shrimp, 1 pound crawfish.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 178

tips.text: Shellfish can be boiled, broiled, baked, steamed, or fried. When done, shelled oysters, mussels, and clams become plump and opaque (or, if cooked in the shells, the shells open up). Oysters curl around the edges. Lobsters and crawfish turn bright red. Shrimp turn pink and scallops turn opaque.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 178

tips.text: Cook live shellfish the same day you buy them. Freeze them immediately in freezer containers: 4-6 to 1 whole Dungeness crab, 1 pound live blue crabs, 1/2 pound crab legs or 3 to 4 ounces lobster tail, 6 ounces shrimp in shells or 3 to 4 ounces peeled shrimp. Cook crabs and lobsters as for eating. Cool, remove meat from shells. Freeze for up to three months. Shuck oysters and scallops; freeze in freezer containers for up to three months.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 178

tips.text: Accept nothing less than the very freshest when buying fish. First, use your nose - fresh fish has a fresh and mild odor. For whole, drawn, or dressed fish: eyes should be clear, bright, and often bulging; gills should be bright red or pink and not slippery; skin should be shiny with the intestinal cavity clean and pink. The flesh should spring back and feel firm and elastic when pressed lightly. Fillets and steaks should have a moist appearance with clean cuts - ragged edges and discoloration indicate poor quality. When buying frozen fish, be sure the flesh is frozen solid and avoid packages with torn wrappers or those with frost.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 165

tips.text: Cook fresh fish as soon as possible, preferably the day you catch it or buy it. If you can't cook it right away, wrap it loosely in clear plastic wrap and refrigerate up to two days. For longer storage, wrap fresh fish in moisture- and vaporproof wrap and freeze. Frozen fish will keep up to 3 months. Store leftover cooked fish, covered, in the refrigerator and use within two days. To thaw fish: place the unopened package in the refrigerator for 6 to 8 hours. Do not thaw fish at room temperature or in water because it will thaw unevenly and may spoil. Don't refreeze fish.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 165

tips.text: To thaw fish in a microwave oven, place 1 pound frozen fillets or steaks in a baking dish. Cover with vented clear plastic wrap. Micro-cook on 30% power (medium-low) for 6 to 8 minutes, turning and separating the fish after 3 minutes. Let fillets stand 10 minutes, and let steaks stand 15 minutes. The fish should be pliable and cold on the outside yet still slightly icy in the centers of thick areas. Rinse and pat dry.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 165

tips.text: Fish selection guide by texture and flavor: FIRM texture with DELICATE flavor: Whitefish, Orange roughy, Lake trout. FIRM with MILD flavor: Tuna (steaks), Sole (fillets), Red snapper, Redfish, Pike (fillets), Ocean perch, Halibut, Flounder, Cod (fillets). FIRM with MILD TO RICH: Swordfish (steaks), Salmon (steaks/fillets). FINE texture with DELICATE: Haddock. FIRM DENSE: Catfish. Rainbow trout is drawn/dressed, partially boned with mild flavor. When substituting fish in recipes, choose fish with similar texture.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 166

tips.text: UNDERCOOKED fish is translucent, with clear juices. The flesh is firm and does not flake easily. PROPERLY COOKED fish is opaque, with milky white juices. The fish flakes easily with a fork. OVERCOOKED fish is opaque and dry. The flesh flakes into little pieces when tested with a fork. Test at the thickest part of the fish.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 167

tips.text: As a general rule, allow 8 to 12 ounces of drawn or dressed fish per serving. Allow 4 to 8 ounces of fish steaks or fillets per serving.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 169

tips.text: Look for firm, bright green spears with tightly closed, compact tips. The cut ends should look fresh and moist, not dried out or woody. Thinner spears are more tender, while thicker spears have more flavor but may need peeling at the base. Avoid bunches with slimy or mushy spots.

For eating fresh: choose yellow bananas with light brown speckles. For baking (muffins, bread): use very ripe bananas with lots of brown spots - they're sweeter and easier to mash. For cooking (fried bananas): use firm, just-yellow bananas. Green bananas are starchy and not yet sweet.

Choose pomegranates that feel heavy for their size - this indicates juicy seeds. The skin should be firm, taut, and free of cracks or soft spots. Color ranges from pink to deep red depending on variety; darker isn't necessarily riper. Ripe pomegranates should have a slightly squared shape from the seeds pressing outward.

Fish can be categorized by texture and oil content for easy substitution. White, firm and rich: Atlantic shad, Chilean sea bass, cobia, bass, Lake trout, Pacific escolar, Pomfret, Sablefish. White, lean and flaky: Atlantic croaker, Black sea bass, Branzino, Flounder, Rainbow smelt, Red snapper, Tilapia, Trout, Weakfish, Whiting. Medium color and oil rich: Amberjack, Arctic char, Coho salmon, Hawaiian kampachi, Mahimahi, Paddlefish, Pompano, Salmon/Sockeye, Wahoo, Yellowfin tuna. Dark and oil rich: Anchovies, Bluefin tuna, Grey mullet, Herring, Mackerel (Atlantic, Boston, King), Salmon (farmed, Chinook), Sardines, Skipjack tuna. White, lean and firm: Alaska pollock, Catfish, Grouper, Haddock, Pacific cod, Pacific halibut, Pacific rockfish, Pacific sand dab, Sole, Striped bass, Swordfish. Generally, you can substitute any fish within one category for another.

When choosing seafood, consider sustainability. The eight safest and most sustainable fish choices are: 1. Albacore Tuna (pole- or troll-caught), 2. Catfish (farmed), 3. Cod (Pacific), 4. Halibut (Pacific), 5. Pollock, 6. Salmon (wild Alaskan), 7. Striped Bass (farmed), 8. Tilapia (farmed). These options are better for the environment and typically have lower mercury levels.
tips.attribution: Cooking Light magazine - Environmental Defense Fund, Monterey Bay Aquarium, Harvard School of Public Health

tips.text: Dried fruits are a healthful, portable snack with many of the same nutritional benefits as fresh counterparts. They're a quick way to add fruit to oatmeal, muffins, scones, and cookies. However, calories are concentrated so enjoy in moderation. Dried Figs (1.5 oz serving): 120 calories, 5.2g fiber, 259mg potassium. Dried Dates (1.5 oz serving): 122 calories, 3.2g fiber, 286mg potassium. A quarter-cup serving of either offers healthy amounts of potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure.
tips.attribution: Cooking Light magazine - Kathy Kitchens Downie, RD

tips.text: Jicama (HEE-kah-ma) is an edible root that resembles a turnip with thin brown skin and crisp, juicy white flesh that's mild in flavor (like a cross between water chestnut and pear). Native to Mexico, it's sometimes called yam bean, Mexican turnip, or Mexican potato. PURCHASE: Find jicama year-round in produce sections and Latin American markets. Select firm, dry roots with skin that doesn't appear shriveled, bruised, or blemished. USE: Remove skin with a sharp vegetable peeler, then cut into cubes or strips. Jicama doesn't brown or become soggy after cutting, making it great for crudit√© platters, salads, sushi rolls (in place of cucumber), and stir-fries. It performs best with quick-cooking methods that maintain crispness. STORE: Keep unpeeled jicama in a plastic bag in the refrigerator for up to two weeks.
tips.attribution: Cooking Light magazine - Executive Chef Billy Strynkowski

tips.text: If muffins have to wait, tip to one side to prevent soggy crusts. To keep warm or reheat muffins, wrap in foil and heat in 400¬∞F oven for 15-20 minutes.
Start soups with saut√©ed onions, celery, and carrots (mirepoix) for the best flavor foundation.
Add a parmesan rind to simmering soup - it adds incredible depth of flavor.
Soups and stews taste better the next day - make them ahead when possible.
Skim fat from the top of soup by dragging a piece of bread or paper towel across the surface.
Always make starter in a glass container. Never store in metal containers or use metal utensils. The starter will react with the metal.
All ingredients, including starter, should be at room temperature (70¬∞F-80¬∞F/21¬∞C-27¬∞C). Cold ingredients will slow down the activity of the yeast.
When removing starter, always replenish it. Let stand at room temperature for 3 to 5 hours, until bubbles start to form. Cover and refrigerate.
If starter separates (liquid forms on surface), stir until blended before using.
If the liquid that forms on surface of starter turns pink in color at any time, discard the starter and start over again with fresh ingredients.

IMPORTANT: Sourdough bread made in an automatic breadmaker requires the addition of yeast. The starter's strength and the rising times in the breadmaker are not sufficient to allow for proper rising without the use of additional yeast.
After baking, pie should be left at room temperature for 2 hours and then refrigerated for 2-3 days.

Unbaked pie mix/filling can be stored in an airtight container for 1 week in the refrigerator or up to 3 months in the freezer. The mix may expand when frozen and may separate, but this will not affect quality or performance. If using a glass pie plate, defrost the crust as well before baking.
To keep unused egg yolk fresh for several days, cover with cold water and store in refrigerator in a covered container.

There are no preservatives in your home made bread, so store cooled loaf in a tightly sealed plastic bag. If desired, enclose a stalk of celery in the bag to keep bread fresh longer. Do not store in the refrigerator as this causes bread to dry out faster.

Use freezer bags, plastic wrap for the freezer in batches; use freezer or canning jars only for liquids. Add one of the following packs as specified: 1) For fruits, add sugar or syrup pack (see chart on pages 194-195) or Unsweetened: Add no sugar or dry pack. Add no sugar. 2) For fruit in the chart (see pages 194-195 for specific fruits). 3) Put time into the freezer containers (see tip, page 193). 4) The amount of headspace depends on (see tip, page 193).
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 189

tips.text: Use frozen vegetables and fruits within 8 to 10 months. Don't thaw vegetables before cooking. Thaw fruit in the refrigerator or in cold water. If the fruit is to be used in a cooked pie, thaw only until fruit will be juicy enough to stir. If the fruit is to be served with ice cream, thaw it enough to be edible at least 4 hours or overnight in the refrigerator or for 1 hour at room temperature.
tips.attribution: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, page 189

tips.text: Treat asparagus like fresh flowers - trim the ends and stand the spears upright in a glass with an inch of water. Cover loosely with a plastic bag and refrigerate. Use within 3-4 days for best quality. Alternatively, wrap the cut ends in a damp paper towel and store in a plastic bag.

Don't wash berries until ready to use - moisture speeds spoilage. Store in a single layer on paper towels in a ventilated container. Strawberries last longer with stems attached. For longer storage, rinse berries in 1 part vinegar to 3 parts water, dry completely, then refrigerate.

Whole lemons last 1 week at room temperature or up to 4 weeks refrigerated. For even longer storage, place in a sealed plastic bag in the fridge - they'll last 4-6 weeks. Cut lemons should be wrapped tightly and used within 2-3 days. Freeze lemon juice in ice cube trays for long-term storage.

For 1 cup buttermilk substitute: Add 1 tablespoon lemon juice or white vinegar to a measuring cup, then fill to 1 cup with regular milk. Let sit 5-10 minutes until slightly curdled. Works well in muffins, pancakes, and quick breads. Plain yogurt thinned with milk also works.

Make your own pumpkin pie spice: 3 tbsp ground cinnamon, 2 tsp ground ginger, 2 tsp ground nutmeg, 1 tsp ground allspice, 1 tsp ground cloves. Mix well and store in an airtight container. Adjust ratios to your taste - some prefer more cinnamon, others more ginger. Freshly ground spices have the best flavor.

For 1 cup cake flour: Measure 1 cup all-purpose flour, remove 2 tablespoons, and replace with 2 tablespoons cornstarch. Sift together 3-4 times to blend well. This approximates cake flour's lower protein content, resulting in more tender cakes and muffins.
Egg substitutes produce an acceptable pie; however the flavor of the spices may be affected because the finished pie texture will be too soft.

Mix wet and dry ingredients separately, then combine just until the flour is moistened - the batter should still look lumpy. Over-mixing develops gluten and creates tough, dense muffins with tunnels. A few streaks of flour are perfectly fine. Let batter rest 15-20 minutes before baking for even better texture.

For consistent results, use the spoon-and-level method: stir flour to loosen it, spoon into measuring cup (don't scoop directly), then level with a straight edge. Scooping packs flour and can add 20-30% more than intended, making baked goods dense and dry.

Room temperature eggs blend more evenly into batters, creating better texture and more volume in cakes. Cold eggs can cause butter to seize up. To quickly warm eggs: place in a bowl of warm (not hot) water for 5-10 minutes. This is especially important for creaming butter-based recipes.

Butter should be pliable but still cool - it should hold its shape when you press it, leaving a slight indent. If it's greasy or shiny, it's too soft. Microwave in 5-second bursts, or cut into cubes and leave at room temp for 30-60 minutes. Too-soft butter won't cream properly and makes cookies spread too much.

Beat softened butter and sugar for 3-5 minutes until light and fluffy. The mixture should be pale yellow and increased in volume. This step incorporates air for tender, light baked goods. Don't rush it - under-creaming leads to dense results. Scrape the bowl occasionally.

Toss berries with a tablespoon of flour before folding into batter - this helps prevent them from sinking to the bottom. For frozen berries, don't thaw first; fold them in frozen to prevent bleeding. Use a gentle folding motion (not stirring) to avoid crushing delicate berries like raspberries.

For deeper flavor, toast bay leaves and paprika (or other spices) in olive oil for a few seconds before adding other ingredients. This brings out the flavor of the spice and gives the dish a delicious warm, earthy quality. This trick works with any spice: ground or whole spices like cumin seeds or cinnamon sticks. It's a simple way to maximize flavor.

When you're short on time, make a habit of piercing tougher cuts of meat with a fork before cooking. The fork breaks up the fibers, which makes the meat more tender. It also helps marinades penetrate quickly below the surface.

When you open a can of beans, your first step is usually to drain and rinse them. But that starchy liquid might be worth saving! It can make your dish thick, creamy, and super flavorful. Try the trick in soups and stews to give them extra body.

A classic Italian meat sauce has a special ingredient that might surprise you: milk! Just ¬Ω cup milk makes rag√π rich but not too creamy, with a subtle sweetness. You probably won't taste the milk in there, but if you leave it out, you'll know that something is missing.
Perhaps you forgot the yeast (we can all err!) or you used stale yeast, extra salt or sugar, or hot liquids that may have killed the yeast and inhibited rising.

Perhaps there was too much liquid or moisture from fruits or vegetables or cheese. It may have risen too fast due to too much yeast. You'll be surprised to find when you cut the top off that you will have a tasty loaf with a coarse texture.
Perhaps there wasn't enough moisture. Sometimes heavier textured breads appear this way.
There was probably too much yeast or moisture.

Perhaps the humidity in the air or the moisture in the flour varied causing the dough to be stickier or drier OR the room temperature was cold or very hot. Remember the machine cannot make judgment calls for those variables.

Perhaps with a heavier bread all the dry ingredients did not get mixed in the kneading; the next time you could try using a rubber spatula to push down ingredients on the sides of the pan, after the first kneading cycle.
The raisins and dates were too sticky. Try air-drying them overnight on the counter or buying date pieces that have a dextrose coating on the outside.
Salt vegetables after cooking, not before - salt draws out moisture and can make them soggy.
Roast vegetables at high heat (400¬∞F+) for better caramelization and flavor.
Don't crowd vegetables in the pan - give them space to brown properly.
Blanch green vegetables in boiling salted water, then shock in ice water to keep their bright color.
